title: R42389
content: Child support is a cash payment that noncustodial parents must pay for their children's financial support. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program, established in 1975, helps secure financial support for children from noncustodial parents and promotes self-sufficiency for families. The program is based on the idea that both parents are responsible for their children's financial well-being. The federal government plays a significant role in funding, monitoring, and evaluating state CSE programs. The CSE program has evolved into a "family-first" service delivery program focused on enhancing family well-being by ensuring reliable child support income. States use various methods, including threats of jail or actual incarceration, to collect child support. Failure to pay child support is considered a crime under state criminal nonsupport statutes, but many states treat it as contempt of court, which can be a civil or criminal offense. Caseworkers in the CSE program have discretion in managing cases. The CSE caseworker has discretion in managing child support cases, including issuing warrants for noncompliant noncustodial parents. Some parents have been arrested after appearing in court. Judges find it challenging to persuade low-income noncustodial parents to pay child support, often resorting to threats of jail as leverage. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program operates nationwide and offers various services for children, including parent location, paternity establishment, and collection of child support payments. The program utilizes different methods to obtain child support obligations, such as income withholding and intercept of tax refunds. Data on the frequency of incarcerating noncustodial parents for nonpayment of child support are not available, making it difficult to gauge the extent of the issue. The Child Support Enforcement program enforces child support obligations through various methods like intercepting tax refunds, withholding income, and seizing assets. States are required to enact UIFSA and full faith and credit procedures for interstate cases. Federal law also allows for international enforcement and imposes criminal penalties in certain cases. Additionally, jurisdictions have contempt-of-court procedures and criminal nonsupport laws to incarcerate noncustodial parents who owe past-due child support. The most effective child support enforcement tool is income withholding, which accounts for about 67% of child support payments collected by states. Other sources of collections include unemployment intercept offset, federal income tax refund offset, and collections through banks and financial institutions. Incarceration as a threat for noncustodial parents who owe child support is estimated to account for less than 2% of total collections. The threat of incarceration for nonpayment of child support can lead to very small chances of receiving payments during the period of incarceration. Before the CSE program in 1975, states attempted to address nonpayment of child support through measures like the Uniform Desertion and Non-Support Act in 1910 and the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act in 1950. The Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act (URESA) was published by State Laws to improve and extend the enforcement of support duties. URESA sought to enforce provisions through criminal and civil enforcement methods. Despite acknowledging the counterproductivity of putting noncustodial parents in jail for child support obligations, criminal enforcement was included in the Act due to its traditional nature and uncertainty if civil enforcement would cover all cases. The threat of extradition was seen as a powerful tool against non-paying parents, categorized as "can't pay" or "won't pay." States and federal government have implemented aggressive enforcement tools for "won't pay" parents, reflecting society's frustration with those who refuse to meet their child support obligations. In some countries, nonresident parents who refuse to pay child support can be sent to prison for up to six weeks. However, not all countries use imprisonment as a method for enforcing child support payments. For example, Australia and Finland do not imprison individuals for failure to pay child support, and Denmark, although it specifies criminal prosecution and imprisonment, has never actually prosecuted or incarcerated anyone for nonpayment of child support. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program has never prosecuted or incarcerated anyone for nonpayment of child support. However, nonpayment can lead to criminal sanctions in three situations: contempt of court for disobeying a child support order, prosecution under state criminal nonsupport statutes, or prosecution under the Child Support Recovery Act. Low-income noncustodial parents are often incarcerated for nonpayment of child support. Contempt of court is a legal term for not following a court order. State courts can punish individuals for violating judgments. Contempt can be civil or criminal, with civil contempt occurring when disobeying a court order. Civil contempt of court occurs when an individual willfully disobeys a court order, leading to potential fines or jail time as a means to coerce compliance rather than punish. This is commonly used in family law to enforce child support orders that have been violated. Compliance with court requirements resolves the contempt issue. Contempt of court can be classified as civil or criminal. Civil contempt is used to coerce compliance with court orders, such as child support payments, while criminal contempt occurs when an individual disrupts court proceedings. Punishments for criminal contempt can include fines, jail time, or both, and are meant to deter future acts of contempt. Unlike civil contempt, criminal contempt charges can persist even after the underlying case is resolved. In civil contempt actions, judges must carefully determine whether to impose civil or criminal contempt of court rulings to avoid wrongful incarceration. Civil contempt is typically used to enforce child support orders against noncustodial parents with poor payment histories or irregular income. Sanctions for civil contempt can include fines paid to the court, compensatory fines paid to the custodial parent, or incarceration. In civil contempt actions, judges must decide on civil or criminal contempt rulings to enforce child support orders. Sanctions can include fines paid to the court, compensatory fines to the custodial parent, or incarceration. The Turner v. Rogers case highlighted that punishment should not be imposed if the alleged contemnor is unable to comply with the order. The noncustodial parent can avoid punishment by meeting the requirements, purging themselves of contempt. The Fourteenth Amendment allows for fewer procedural protections in civil contempt cases compared to criminal cases. In criminal contempt proceedings, defendants must be provided with essential due process protections, including notice of the offense, the right to present a defense, call witnesses, an impartial judge, and in some cases, the right to counsel and a trial by jury. The process is more complex than in civil contempt cases, potentially involving an indigency hearing, a jury trial, and a change of judge. In criminal contempt cases, defendants are entitled to due process protections, including notice of the offense, the right to present a defense, call witnesses, an impartial judge, and in some cases, the right to counsel and a trial by jury. Criminal contempt may be effective in cases where a noncustodial parent repeatedly fails to make child support payments until facing jail time. Jail terms can be set consecutively for multiple contempt rulings, and criminal contempt may be the only remedy for parents who intentionally limit their ability to pay child support. Noncustodial parents found guilty of contempt can be jailed unless they satisfy the child support obligation. The U.S. Supreme Court in Turner v. Rogers declined to rule that due process requires legal representation for indigent noncustodial parents facing imprisonment for noncompliance with child support orders. Instead, the court emphasized procedural safeguards such as notice, financial information disclosure, opportunity to respond, and court findings on ability to pay. This case involved a South Carolina child support dispute. The defendant, Michael Turner, spent a year in jail for failure to pay back child support in a South Carolina case. The court did not determine his ability to pay or indigent status. Turner was held in contempt of court, not convicted of a crime, and the jail time was a means to induce payment of past-due child support. The Court in Turner v. Rogers emphasized procedural safeguards over legal representation for indigent noncustodial parents facing imprisonment for noncompliance with child support orders. The Court in Turner v. Rogers emphasized procedural safeguards over legal representation for indigent noncustodial parents facing imprisonment for noncompliance with child support orders. The decision did not mandate appointment of an attorney but highlighted the importance of ensuring notice and access to financial information for fair proceedings. The debate over nonpaying noncustodial parents being seen as deadbeats or turnips is a contentious issue. Some argue that those with high child support arrears are deadbeats who neglect their responsibilities, while others believe that low-income parents are like turnips, unable to afford payments. The threat of jail is seen as necessary for some to comply with child support, while others argue that many low-income parents simply cannot afford to pay. According to analysts and Turner's legal team, individuals who cannot afford to pay child support often end up in jail, depriving them of freedom and job opportunities. In civil contempt cases, defendants can end jail time by complying with the order, but lack of funds or legal representation can hinder this. Turner likened his situation to debtors' prison, while the mother of his children argued against granting civil contempt defendants the right to counsel to avoid inequality in the justice system. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to grant indigent criminal defendants the right to court-appointed attorneys in civil proceedings that could lead to jail time, as seen in the Turner case. However, the Court found that sentencing someone to imprisonment without determining their ability to pay violated their constitutional rights. Child Support Enforcement (CSE) actions may resort to criminal charges for nonpayment, with state and federal laws addressing nonsupport of children. In some states, child support attorneys can file criminal charges against noncustodial parents for nonpayment, serving as a deterrent. Criminal nonsupport proceedings are used after civil remedies are exhausted, with normal rules of evidence applying. This can be effective when civil remedies have failed or the parent is evading payment. The normal rules of evidence apply to criminal nonsupport actions, initiated by filing a complaint or indictment. A judge may issue a warrant or summons based on initial findings, with the standard of proof being beyond a reasonable doubt. The Child Support Recovery Act of 1992 addressed interstate enforcement of child support to prevent noncustodial parents from avoiding payment by moving to another state. The Child Support Recovery Act of 1992 imposed federal criminal penalties for willful failure to pay child support obligations to out-of-state children, targeting difficult interstate cases where traditional enforcement methods had failed. Penalties included fines and imprisonment, serving as an additional enforcement tool for noncustodial parents evading their obligations. The Deadbeat Parents Punishment Act of 1998 established felony offenses for evading child support obligations, with a two-year maximum prison term. The law targets interstate cases with unpaid obligations over $5,000 or $10,000, enforced through the Project Save Our Children initiative by federal agencies. Project Save Our Children is a collaborative effort by various agencies to pursue delinquent parents who owe child support. In FY2006, the program received over 10,000 cases, resulting in 986 arrests and $39.6 million in restitution ordered. In FY2007, $8.1 million was collected from 1,139 cases. The threat of jail encourages compliance, but low-income parents may go to jail if unable to pay. Noncustodial parents who cannot afford to pay child support may end up in jail as a result of the threat of incarceration. Despite efforts to coerce payment through this threat, many low-income parents lack the means to comply. Analysts question the effectiveness of this policy, as imprisoning parents who are already financially strained does not necessarily benefit the children involved. The threat of jail may not be effective if it is known that the parent is unable to pay. Many noncustodial fathers feel the Child Support Enforcement (CSE) system is dismissive of their financial struggles and continues to pursue payments even when they can barely support themselves. They argue that the program benefits the government more than their child, leading to conflicts with the child's mother who may use threats of reporting to authorities or court action. Critics warn that incarceration for nonpayment can turn nonviolent individuals into aggressive ones due to the harsh environment of jails. Many believe jails should primarily house violent offenders, not nonviolent ones like those jailed for nonpayment of child support. Violence is seen as a normal part of prison life, with high rates of physical assault. It is suggested that less harsh alternatives should be considered for nonviolent offenders. According to the ACLU, incarceration has a devastating impact on individuals who are poor, including those with unpaid legal financial obligations like child support. After release, they struggle to rebuild their lives due to reduced income, worsened credit, and limited housing and employment opportunities. These legal debts can become insurmountable barriers, leading to a cycle of financial hardship and potential re-incarceration. Many individuals are tethered to the criminal justice system due to unmanageable legal debts, facing constant threat of re-incarceration. Jail can negatively impact mental and physical health, leading some inmates to adopt aggressive personas for self-preservation. Self-medication with drugs is common, affecting parent-child relationships and contributing to recidivism. Putting nonviolent individuals in jail is seen as counterproductive, especially with overcrowding and tight budgets. The United States has the highest incarceration rate globally. The Pew Center on the States reported that 1 in every 100 adults in the United States now lives behind bars, with corrections costs exceeding $65 billion per year. Many states and localities are using alternatives to incarceration, such as community service and electronic monitoring, to save costs and improve the criminal justice system. Policy analysts argue that incarcerating individuals for nonviolent offenses like nonpayment of child support is counterproductive and disproportionately affects low-income noncustodial parents, especially African Americans. Many CSE officials argue that noncustodial parents are not penalized for being poor but for being "deadbeats." They believe judges give chances to avoid jail if sincere effort is shown to pay child support. Demonstrating job search efforts and low income can convince the court to avoid jail time. It is not a crime to be poor, but a noncustodial parent with no income could still end up in jail, even if they acknowledge their child support responsibilities. Many noncustodial parents argue that being unemployed and unable to meet child support obligations can lead to being labeled as a deadbeat and facing jail time. They feel that CSE caseworkers have too much power in deciding when to involve the courts, leading to immediate arrest and incarceration without exploring other options. Unlike other felons, noncustodial parents jailed for nonpayment of child support cannot receive credit for the support owed during their time in jail. Noncustodial parents in jail for nonpayment of child support cannot substitute time served for payments. Incarceration isolates parents from their children, weakening bonds and impacting families and communities. The social, psychological, and emotional effects on children should be considered, as well as the difficulties ex-convicts face in finding employment, perpetuating a cycle of hardship. In recent years, mandating work/training programs for low-income noncustodial parents as an alternative to incarceration has been considered. Noncustodial parents are given chances to pay child support before jail time. CSE agencies may negotiate payment plans or forgive arrearages. Failure to pay child support leads to reduced income for children. Some argue that not meeting child support obligations should be treated as a crime. Operating prisons humanely is costly, and incarceration is for legitimate reasons. In recent years, there has been consideration for mandating work/training programs as an alternative to incarcerating low-income noncustodial parents who fail to pay child support. Despite the availability of various enforcement tools, incarceration remains a method used by Child Support Enforcement (CSE) agencies. Policymakers believed that the threat of jail would compel noncustodial parents to pay their child support debts. The historical perspective was that the CSE program needed punitive measures for noncompliant parents. Many states have criminal sanctions for noncustodial parents who fail to pay child support, often resulting in imprisonment. Some parents try to avoid their obligations by hiding or working in the underground economy. The Child Support Enforcement program has improved in locating noncustodial parents and their income. Many noncustodial parents end up in jail for nonpayment of child support due to lack of income or means to pay. Critics argue that incarcerating these individuals, who are often low-income, is counterproductive as it hinders their future prospects. While some custodial parents acknowledge that some noncustodial parents are genuinely unable to pay, they urge caution in lowering child support orders. The states and federal government should be cautious in lowering child support orders for low-income noncustodial parents and avoiding incarceration. Child support is crucial for families to avoid poverty, and reducing orders may harm the child's income. Noncustodial parents, even in financial hardship, should still contribute to their children. It is essential to prevent unpaid support build-up through early intervention to benefit the child. The CSE Strategic Plan aims to strengthen the child support enforcement system by modifying orders to align with ability to pay, contacting noncustodial parents promptly after missed payments, updating guidelines to reflect modern family dynamics, using automation for early noncompliance detection, and prioritizing consistent current support payments. Effective modification processes can prevent inappropriate child support debt accumulation and ensure orders remain appropriate. States have flexibility in modifying and reviewing child support orders under the CSE program. Some analysts argue for child support modification laws to be more sensitive to periods of incarceration, unemployment, or injury/illness that affect the noncustodial parent's ability to pay. In cases where the obligation cannot be met, in-kind assistance like child care could be considered to support the well-being of children while acknowledging financial challenges. Many argue for non-incarceration remedies for low-income noncustodial parents to support their children's well-being and address financial challenges. Innovative approaches like probation, drug abuse prevention programs, and work/training programs are seen as effective alternatives to incarceration, which can hinder familial relationships and employment opportunities post-release. The high costs of using the criminal justice system for nonviolent offenders can be alleviated by revamping it to fund alternatives. State and federal initiatives aim to mitigate the harmful impacts of father absence through responsible fatherhood and CSE access programs, providing job opportunities for low-income noncustodial parents to meet child support obligations. Noncustodial parents with a criminal record face challenges in meeting child support obligations due to limited job prospects and barriers to employment. Imposing jail time can be counterproductive as it hinders their ability to work and earn money, increasing the risk of re-incarceration. Additionally, support orders are often not reduced while parents are incarcerated, further exacerbating financial difficulties. Noncustodial parents face challenges meeting child support obligations while incarcerated, leading to accumulating arrears and interest. Support arrears are owed to the state, not the child or custodial parent, hindering the noncustodial parent's ability to secure employment post-release. This cycle of debt and lack of employment increases the likelihood of re-incarceration for nonpayment of child support. Noncustodial parents facing child support obligations can benefit from work or job training programs instead of jail. Judges can mandate nonpaying parents of children receiving TANF benefits to participate in a work program or face jail time. Monitoring ensures compliance, potentially leading to job opportunities or payment of child support. Programs like the Texas Noncustodial Parent Choices Program and Fathering Court offer alternatives to incarceration for noncustodial fathers. DC offers an alternative to prosecuting noncustodial fathers with child support arrears. Transitional Jobs programs provide job opportunities for struggling parents. State CSE programs partner with workforce boards to help low-income parents meet child support obligations. Some wonder about the effectiveness of mandatory work programs for nonpaying parents. Incarceration as a last resort for nonpayment of child support is seen as a logical option due to the moral and financial obligation parents have towards their children. All states have criminal sanctions for nonpayment of child support, reflecting the seriousness of the issue. In the 1990s, nonpayment of child support was increasingly viewed as a serious crime, with some states even having a "most wanted" list for child support debtors. In the late 1990s, states began using jail as a last resort for child support enforcement. State statutes include penalties such as jail time and fines for failure to pay child support.
